name: Olympiade
description:
Each player has 6 pieces. Two value 1, two value 2 & two value 3.
They place 1 of these in each of the six sports (Running, Swimming, Javelin, Pole Vault, Rowing & Show Jumping).
A die (D3) is rolled & multiplied by the value of the piece to determine how far or high they have managed. This is repeated until the event is complete & Gold, Silver & Bronze are awarded appropriately. Some events may require particular values to be attained in order to continue.
Once all 6 events are complete, points for the medals are added up to decide the winner.

name: En 2 mots
description:
Players are divided into teams. The "leaders" of each team are made aware of five words to guess in less than a minute bidding and who will use the fewest words to discover them. If the winner succeeds, his team won the map.

Not very original, but with a neat material, which allows you to play great assemblies.

name: Spectacula Gladiatora
description:
A hex based gladitorial combat game. You run a school of gladiators in ancient Rome.You can use chits or miniatures. The system of combat favors fast, bloody games instead of complexity and minute detail. It was designed to be familiar to role players and a entry point for casual players to become familiar with historical gaming.

The goal of the game is to win the most money by determining when is the best time to fight or use manipulation to increase your pocket book.

Each player starts with finances predetermined before playing. This amount can be changed each game to allow for shorter or longer campaigns. The players the purchases fighters for their stable, armor and can invest in creating better stats for their fighters.
In later editions the rules added a political component for multi-player campaigns.

name: Esel Lino
description:
Objective: be the first getting rid of all your cards
- acting by turn -
1. put all five '1' cards face up into middle of the desk, take out the donkey card; all other cards are shuffled and handed out
2. each player forms a pile, cards face down
3. draw top card; if you can discard it - must match colour & must show a value of +1 (='2' in the very first moment/round) put it into the middle ==> form a pile
3a. if it doesn't match ==> form your open pile next to you... ==> next player's turn
4. draw top card; if you can discard it - must match colour & must show a value of +1 ==> desk pile (priority!)
OR ==> must show a value of +/- 1 & no need of matching colour to place on top open pile of one of your opponents
5. if your face down pile is empty turn your open pile face down
6. if active player misses an opportunity to discard or plays wrong sequence ==> gets penalty: donkey card & 1 card from each opponent
content: 100 cards numbered 1-20/5 colours

+ 1 donkey & 3 joker cards

remarks:
less enjoyable with 2 players

name: ni Oui ni Non: Autour du Monde
description:
900 questions around the world (in English).

Object of the game is during the questions try other players
to answer forbidden words YES or NO. If somebody answer so
others must then quickly ring the bell to move their pawn on the gameboard if they are the quickest.

The winner is who gets there first with his character in the middle of the board.

Contents:

1 game board,
110 cards, including 55 for children (orange) and 55 adult (green),
1 bell,
6 characters.

name: ni Oui ni Non: Stars & Co
description:
900 questions are divided into two groups (young and old), relate to the world of sports stars and showbiz.

Object of the game is during the questions try other players
to answer forbidden words YES or NO. If somebody answer so
others must then quickly ring the bell to move their pawn on the gameboard if they are the quickest.

The winner is who gets there first with his character in the middle of the board.

Contents:

1 game board,
110 cards, including 55 for children (orange) and 55 adult (green),
1 bell,
6 characters.
categories: Card Game, Music, Party Game, Real-time, Sports

name: Kelbazar Junior
description:
El Bazar junior version.

Simple game in which players are trying to make something that they have on drawn tile (an animal, an object, a thing) using wooden elements. When the opponent guesses what you are building you both score a point. If not, next players is trying to make others to guess.

Text on the backside of the box:
How can a plane, a watering can or even a doll be presented using wooden shapes? Guaranteed giggles for the whole family...

Contents:

120 tiles (toys, animals and objects)
17 wooden shapes
sand timer
categories: Action / Dexterity, Animals, Children's Game, Deduction

name: Rally Point Volleyball
description:
This is a game of women's collegiate volleyball (Division I). Players are rated for their ability to kill, set, block, serve, and dig. Three, ten-sided dice are used to resolve Actions from the Action Chart. All Actions require the comparison of two ratings. Depending on the outcome of the ratings checked, teams can score big, score small, or get scored against.

All 329 Division I teams are rated in 32 separate conferences. The game includes all charts and tables, a rule book, and the Final 32 from the 2011 NCAA Division I tournament.

name: Monopoly: Osnabrück
description:
A monopoly (from Greek monos μόνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεῖν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements from Osnabrück, in Germany.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: The National Parks Game
description:
Explore the vast American wilderness and preserve the natural features you discover in order to create the greatest collection of national parks. A quick, simple deck building card game for two players.

The object of the game is to establish national parks, each of which requires a certain combination of natural features--wildlife, trees, geology, geothermal, mountains, water and desert. To discover these features, players explore (purchase) natural feature cards from a central row of five, which go into their deck. The feature icons on these cards can be used to establish parks, or to explore additional feature cards.
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Set Collection

name: Charger
description:
It's a game about jousting. The object is to remove both your opponents knights.

The game is played on board with two lines of holes which the knights fit in. Each player has two knights which are positioned facing the opposing player on one side of the board.

Player 1 moves one of his knights 1 space, the player 2 moves one of his knights 2 spaces, player 1 moves one of his knights 3 spaces. Each player continues to move a piece one hole further than his opponent's last move until one of the pieces reaches an end hole where it turns and complete its move in the opposite direction.

When an end has been reached or 'bounced off' the opponent's next move distance reverts to 1, each move again being one higher until an end is again reached by any piece.

A player must move his pieces forwards until one of them has reached the opponent's end of the board, thereafter both pieces may move in either direction.

When a pieces finishes its move alongside an opponent's piece, it scores a "hit" and the opponent's piece is removed, when a player loses both of his pieces he has lost.

name: Citizen News
description:
The object is to become the richest player or own a majority of 15 shares in at least three of the 10 newspapers in the game.

In his turn player choose one of a following action:

Buys or sells shares to other players
Buys shares in the bank to their value, that each log is represented by 15 shares increasing in value 10 000 (pr 1) 150 000 (for 15 °).
Take tokens '+' & '-' depending on the number of shares it has. These chips will raise or lower profits of newspapers
Place each token on a security that one has


and additionally player simultainously reveal the chips and adjusted earnings per share. Then each gets its profits or pays its losses.

It is repeated until one player reaches the goal.

name: The Four Gods
description:
User summary

A Japanese home-published tile/card game. The game starts with a setup of face down square tiles that have power lines on their face up side. Players choose one of the edge positions as their "exit" to empower, and take turns either turning up, rotating or echanging one of the earth tiles, with the goal of getting as many connected tiles as possible to their "exit". Once the exit has a set number of connected earth tiles, it's Sealed, and the first player to Seal four exits wins.

Players can also play cards from their hand for further effects.

name: Un fine settimana a Roma
description:
The game board shows a map of Rome. Players roll a die and move through the city, trying to reach the famous sites (especially those two whose cards they drew at the beginning and which are marked). Other means of transportation can be used to get around more quickly, but they have to be paid for in travel chips. When a player reaches a site, s/he is asked a question. If answering correctly, the site card can be discarded and a new travel chip is drawn. When reaching an unmarked site, they can earn a new site card (if that belongs to someone else, it can be "stolen").
When a player can reach both sites they drew at the beginning and gain two more site cards and return to their starting location, s/he wins the game.

Questions come in two difficulty levels, as the game is designed for language learning. So the difficulty does not refer to the knowledge needed to answer the question, but to the Italian speaking ability.

name: Un week-end a Paris
description:
The game board shows a map of Paris. Players roll a die and move through the city, trying to reach the famous sites (especially those two whose cards they drew at the beginning and which are marked). Additionally, taxis, buses and the tube can be used to get around more quickly, but they have to be paid for in travel chips. When a player reaches a site, s/he is asked a question. If answering correctly, the site card can be discarded and a new travel chip is drawn. When reaching an unmarked site, they can earn a new site card (if that belongs to someone else, it can be "stolen").
When a player can reach both sites they drew at the beginning and gain two more site cards and return to their starting location, s/he wins the game.

Questions come in two difficulty levels, as the game is designed for language learning. So the difficulty does not refer to the knowledge needed to answer the question, but to the French speaking ability.

name: Experten Quiz SEGELN
description:
Objective:
find correct answers for questions out of the world of sailing
- acting by turn -
decision: form 2 teams or act as 'lone fighters'
give fast & correct answers on questions like:
What kind of shoes are used for sailing?
Maximum wheight for a boat participating in the 'America's Cup'?

content:
50 cards with 150 questions, multiple-choice-answers and detailed explanations on the back of the cards
remarks:
game belongs to a series: 'Experten Quiz'
categories: Card Game, Educational, Party Game, Sports, Trivia

name: Speak Up!
description:
In Speak Up!, everyone plays in one of five languages – German, English, French, Spanish or Italian – and not knowing the language won't necessarily be a detriment.

To set up the game, lay out 49 of the fifty cards on the table with the picture side faceup; next to the picture is the name of the item in five languages. The back of each card features the name of some other item in five languages.

To start play, take the card set aside during set-up and read one of the words on the back, say "Markt" (the German word for "market"). Everyone then races to find the card depicting the market, which will also have the various words for "market" next to the picture. Whoever finds it keeps the card, then flips it over and reads the German word on the back. This process continues until all the cards have been claimed. Whoever has the most cards wins!

name: P.B.G.: President, Balayeur, General
description: The goal in this card game is to climb up the career ladder to make as much money as possible. Each player is randomly assigned a profession at the start of the game; then a trick taking game is played in which each player holds six hidden cards plus some (depending on the number of players) cards which are drawn openly. The rank of the profession determines how players may talk to each others, mistakes are punished by penalty cards. After finishing a round, a player is demoted if s/he has more cards of the profession below him/her plus penalty cards. Promotions are then resolved as a result of demotions, and everybody gets their salary. The first player to own 100000 Euros is the winner.

name: The Askalite
description:
Traditional quiz game where a player must answer a question by placing the wired connector to the slot of his chosen answer and, if correct, the bulb attached to that answer will light up. Subjects provided are:
Who was, Where is, Translate, History, General Knowledge and one which asked you to write your own questions and answers.
Most correct answers, wins.

Instructions from the rules:
Connect the two wires to a battery - one player should place one of the perforated sheets so that the holes in it fit exactly over the little knobs. Players in turn take the left wander-plug and with it touch any one of the knobs on the question side (the left), then try to find the right answer on the right hand side. If the player thinks he has found the correct reply, the right hand plug should be placed in contact with the knob in the square which he thinks contains the correct answer. When the correct answer is found, the lamp light up.

name: Who's Got Game? The Game with Benefits by Neil Strauss
description:
SUMMARY:

Neil Strauss, seven-time New York Times bestselling author who brought you the international bestselling seduction books The Game and Rules of the Game is back with one question in mind: “Who’s Got Game?”

“Who’s Got Game?” adds a new twist to being social and can be played anywhere. Whether or not you’re currently a player or playette, there is more game in this box than in most people’s brains. Play it for fun, for training, or for a better social lubricator than alcohol. Like The Game itself, these cards can be used to break the ice and get to know people—whether strangers or your own partner—in minutes.

“Who’s Got Game?” is engineered to bring out the fun and attractive qualities in every player. From physical challenges to personality tests to secret conspiracies, “Who’s Got Game?” has it all. So if you’re looking to turn an ordinary night into a memorable adventure, this is the game for you.

OBJECTIVE:

Players take turns running game (script cards) on each other. The player with the most points after 12 script cards + The Final Challenge wins!

HOW TO PLAY:

Each round, one player is THE LEADER. THE LEADER reads a script card aloud to all the players. The script card, for example, can consist of personality tests, fun loaded questions, charade-like questions, handwriting analysis, palm reading, physical challenges, secret conspiracy missions, and more. The players respond to the script card accordingly. The player(s) who win the round receives points. (The script card states how many points the card is worth.) After each script card is completed, the next player going clockwise becomes THE LEADER. The player with the most points after 12 script cards + The Final Challenge wins.
mechanics: Acting, Paper-and-Pencil, Pick-up and Deliver, Storytelling, Trick-taking

name: Bestiary
description:
Bestiary is a simple card driven two player game in which players create chimeras by adding different creature parts.

Drawing creature part cards from a common deck, players take turns to put them into play. When a card is played, a control marker is placed on it. Creature parts can be tails, middle parts or heads. A chimera is completed when it has a tail and a head. Several chimeras may be incomplete at the same time. A player may choose to discard a card and draw a new one instead of playing a card, or may choose to pass. When two players pass consecutively or the deck is depleted, the game ends. Players then earn score according to the sum of values printed on the creature part cards they played which form completed chimeras.
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Print & Play

name: Sia Doble
description: Sia Doble appears to be a two-player version of Oliver Schaudt's Sia Solo, a solitaire puzzle game in which the solver tries to swap the positions of two large stones on the game board. In Sia Doble, each player has three large stones and – I'm saying this based totally on gut-feeling – needs to place those stones in the starting spaces of the opponent's stones in order to win.

name: RoleChess
description:
RoleChess
is a combination of Chess and a role game that is played with pieces similar to those used in Chess. The movements of pieces differ a bit from those of the pieces used in Chess. Nevertheless, the biggest difference from Chess is in the progress of the game.
Different types of pieces possess an energy amount of their own, and additionally, they have certain attack and defense coefficients, which when multiplied by the number of spots of a dice, determine the attack or defense score of the piece in question in a battle. The difference between the attack and defense score affects the energy amount to be lost by the pieces.

The aim of the game is to reduce the opponent’s Emperor’s energy amount to zero, while at the same time protecting one’s own Emperor from the same fate. The player who is the first to beat the opponent’s Emperor will win the game.

Product materials
Board and pieces are fully made of real wood. Game board is made of pine tree and game pieces are made of basswood. Game box is made of cardboard.
Product is designed in Finland and is manufactured in China. All components used in this product are environmentally friendly and information is found of all components. Product has a CE marking.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Role Playing

name: Guido Buchwald's WM-Fun
description:
Objective: score most goals - try to keep your goal clean
- acting by turns -
roll the die, move, draw action cards, manipulate playing time, participate in a soccer camp, move to substitutes' bench, challenge other players with penalty shootout...
game ends at the end of the second half or if one player scores 24 goals

remarks:
Guido Buchwald is a former German soccer player

name: Wehrmacht
description:
Wehrmacht is a diceless science fiction miniatures wargame depicting combat between giant, piloted, robotic warmachines called Knights. Each player controls a cadre of Knights that fights for a Royal House in a far future Feudalocracy.

The game is played on a tabletop using miniatures for the Knights and representative scenery. Knights perform actions using an alternating sequence. When activated, a Knight may move (via measurement in inches on the tabletop) and perform an attack action. The combat system is diceless and invovles comparing an attacker's Fire Control System (FCS) or Melee Control System (MCS) rating to the target's Evasion Control Systems (ECS) rating. If the ECS is exceeded, an attack hits and does damage. At the beginning of each turn, players secretly select a Combat Mode for each Knight that determines its basic FCS, MCS, and ECS ratings for the turn. These ratings may be modified by various upgrades and other actions that may be taken during the game.

name: Das Manager Spiel
description:
Objective: score most winning points (after agreed time)
by acting successfully as a manager
- acting by turn -
each player becomes a manager during a whole turn (probably several times):
during his/her management phase player is challenged (by cards)
- red = event cards (draw and act until a blue card is drawn)
- blue = task card
manager must announce his task and distribute (hidden) the roles cards (printed on the blue card);
now it's time to perform and deliver within a certain time (hour glass) - and afterwards each player has to vote (hidden) according to his/her specific role;
due to performance manager has several options increasing the score (betting) or finding the 'bastard'(additional points);
categories: Action / Dexterity, Humor, Mature / Adult, Word Game
mechanics: Acting, Betting and Bluffing, Open Drafting, Simulation

name: Mummel
description:
Mummel is a game where the players take turns in the role of the reader. Based on a spin on a wheel the reader do one of six actions.

Read a new card asking "Who said: [quote]?"
Read a new card asking "What did [Celebrity] say about [fact]?"
Read a new card asking "Finish the quote: [uncomplete quote]!"
Steal a collected card from one player
Give a collected card to anoter player
Force another player to exchange one card with you.

The Read actions has about 25% each to occur.
The actions using allready collected card share the remaining 25% chance.

If a new card is read the players write their answers in secret.
The reader collects the answers ans checks if any of them are correct. The player closest in turn to the reader who has the right answer gets the card that was read. If no one has the right answer (usually the case :) the reader reads all the answers and the correct answer and the player closest in turn that guess which one is correct gets the card. If no one guess correct the reader gets the card.

The back of the cards (seen by the players when the reader reads) are marked with four different synbols. The one who is first at collecting at least one of all four symbols wins.
categories: Bluffing, Card Game, Party Game, Trivia, Word Game

name: Trivial Pursuit: Édition Europa
description:
Each player has a circular playing piece with six pie-shaped holes. The goal of the game is to collect a pie in each color. The colors correspond to different questions in the following categories:

Blue: Places of Europe
Pink: Live in Europe
Yellow: Institutions of Europe
Brown: Culture of Europe
Green: History of Europe
Orange: Personalities of Europe

The board consists of a circular track with spaces in seven different colors. Six of the colors correspond to question categories while the last color gives a new dice roll. Six spaces along the track are "pie spaces", and from these there are "spokes" of track leading to the middle of the board.

Players roll a die and move along the track in any direction they like. When a player stops on a color they get a question of the appropriate category. If the player answers a question correctly while on a pie space, they get a pie of that color (assuming they don't already have it). A correct answer on another square allows the player to roll again.

Once the player has one pie in each color, she can move along the spokes to the middle of the board to win the game.

name: Shadow
description:
Logical deduction game. Each player starts with a grid of 7 x 7 squares. Both boards must be hidden from the opponent. One player (the Target) marks his starting point in the centre square of the grid. The other player (the Shadow) starts at any one of the four corner squares.

The objective for the Target is to visit two of the four corner squares without being captured. The objective of the Shadow is to capture the Target by landing on the corresponding square.

The Target moves orthagonally and must keep a record of his moves by tracing a line from his start point through all the squares he travels over during the game. The Shadow moves like a Knight in Chess. Information is given each turn to enable both players to get some idea where the other is.

name: Magery
description: 2 Player game with fantasy theme that combines chess with worker placement. Minions of 8 types are used as both chess pieces, some with unique moves, and also as workers. Each round players take turns placing their minions into the 16 available Tower Chambers. Each chamber holds a distinct Mage that grants a special power, such as adding a minion to the board or moving a specific type of minion on the board. Players then take turns removing their minions from the tower to activate these powers. 12 chaos mages are available to mix things up. Win by capturing your opponents greater minions or by wiping him off the board.

name: Sqez
description:
The playing-field of Sqez is a rectilinear array of dots, of any convenient size — but arrays of less than 8 x 8 are too small, and exceptionally large fields may prolong the game needlessly, unless there are many players. The easiest way to make the arrays is to type up rows of full-stops on a typewriter; but it's just possible that somewhere or other you can buy dotted paper (wallpaper?), and it wouldn't be hard to get used to playing on small-squared graph paper, counting each inter¬section as a 'dot'. But I leave this to your ingenuity.
Each player in Sqez must complete a rectangle (oblong or square) by drawing a line through the dots. The line drawn must not anywhere duplicate an already placed line, though it may cross another line, or meet it at one end; and the rectangle drawn must enclose at least one 'free' dot — a free dot being defined as a dot that has no line passing through it or originating at it. The last player to complete a legal move is the winner.
Those are the entire rules, except to say that a player who places a line which he cannot (owing to miscalculation) use to make a legal move (by completing a rectangle as defined) forfeits the game.

name: The Battle of the Bulge
description:
"The Battle of the Bulge" is an operational level wargame for Ardennes Offensive. There are other games of the same name, but this one is a unique game that is designed for the wargame beginner

Players will control either German Army or Allied Army. Players manage movement and combat by basic hex and counter mechanism.
The game winner is determined by control of the important cities and exit to the map.

Game scale: 6km per hex, 1 day per turn, a division per unit

First published with Tanks and Tenka fubu in one box titled "Simulation games for beginner #1".
Republished as Command Magazine Japan #120 in 2014.
publishers: Epoch, Kokusai-Tsushin Co., Ltd. (国際通信社)

name: Generation Game
description:
TV related game based on one of Britain's favourite shows. Essentially, contestants took part in various games and skills (mainly for their comedy value) and the game captures that flavour. Accrue points and "points mean prizes" as Bruce Forsyth (pictured on the box) famously once said. Catchphrases were Bruce's speciality and he is the originator of the most famous ones.

Browsers might know the famous Beat the Clock television show on both sides of the Atlantic and this has a certain element of that show in its style.
categories: Action / Dexterity, Humor, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Peter Rabbit's Puzzle Game
description:
A game for younger children.

On their turn, each player rolls a regular die. The number they roll indicates which part of their Beatrix Potter character card that they can 'assemble'. Unusually for these sort of games, like Beetle, is that you need nine parts to your character. Number 1 represents each corner piece so you will need to roll a 1 four times to assemble each corner of your picture.

The first to finish their Peter Rabbit character picture, wins.

name: Willow
description:
Willow is a poker-like gambling game with a simpler hand structure. Each player has two cards. The best possible hand is a pair and other hands are ranked by the difference between the two cards: the greater the difference, the better the hand!

Willow uses a deck of 36 cards. Use a standard playing deck but remove the jokers, kings, and every card of a single suit.

Willow is part of the Poker Suite compilation by Cheapass Games.

name: Know Your Navy
description:
Unusual game in that it was made by the Royal Navy Careers Service, as a tool to attract youngsters to a career choice.

From the rules card:
How to become an expert at recognising the shlps. missiles and aircraft of the Royal Navy.
You can use these cards in many ways that will help you memorise the 'hardware’ of today’s Royal Navy.

A Recognition Quiz is one game you can play. Each card is numbered so you earn that number of points for every ship you Identify,

Here are two card games you can play:
Navy Snap—Deal seven or more cards to each player. Place remainder of pack in centre of table. Play in rotation, each player trying to match from his own hand the top card of the table pack (which is discarded on to a second pile).
Players match cards by producing any ship of the same type — i.e. any class of frigate with any other class of frigate; a nuclear sub with a nuclear sub but any non-nuclear class of sub with any other non-nuclear.
Players may be challenged on their matching and. If they have mixed one type with another, they have to take their card back and forfeit their throw next time round.
First player out wins.

Navy Rummy — Deal seven cards to each player. Play like ordinary rummy, collecting sets of three (i.e. three subs of any type. three aircraft. three ships of any type) and runs of four (in ascending or descending order of displacement tonnage — i.e. carriers, auxiliaries, cruisers. Polaris subs, missile destroyers, frigates and so on).
First player out wins.

Win a presentation colour picture for your own idea. If you think up a game of your own — which must be simple as well as fun — let's know about it at the address on the other side of this card. If we like It we’ll send a presentation colour picture of a modern Royal Navy ship or aircraft.

name: TV Times Square Eyes
description:
British quiz game, linked to the TV Times, Britains listing magazine for non-BBC TV channels.

The cards have images on them relating someone or a series that should be familiar to you. You get 20 seconds to study the card before being challenged by questions about the image. Correct answers help you move round the board which goes through four different TV channels. If you are first to the Off Switch, you win.

name: Got You!
description:
Three dimensional abstract game. The board is plastic and stands between the players (as the Connect 4 board does). In a turn, a player may either:
Drop a disc into the board; or...
Move the current discs by operating a slide at the side.

Thus, you may add to the board or manipulte discs already in the board.

The winner is the first player to get three discs of their colour in a row.

name: Cédric Sacrée journée
description:
Cedric like to be photographed with Chen, his girlfriend. But Chen agreed only if he pass a perfect day to be a good boy. He must collect points to charm the girl and then run to the place where she waits to be photographed with him.

There is a journey through the day of Cedric on the gameboard. Beginning with the square "Start of the day" and ending with the square "end of the day" where players is able to pose with Chen.

In his turn player rolls the color die and move his game-piece
to next square with rolled color. Then he may pass a test to roll a number dice and get a result greater or equal than the number on the box. If the test is successful he adds the points he has just won the score noted on their file and writes it on the notes (with erasable marker).

Each player has 3 event cards he may use in his turn to help provide bonuses to its dice rolls.

The first player who reaches the finish square and pose with Chen is the winner.
categories: Children's Game, Dice, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Racing

name: National Park Wit
description: One of a series of Wit trivia games, National Park Wit has 105 cards with questions about National Parks. On the back of each card is a different photo from a National Park and a point value from 1-10 and 15. On the front of each card are three trivia questions and answers, as well as a description of the picture on the back. In turn, each player is asked a question of the asker's choice from the three on the card. If he gets the question right, he keeps the card. If he gets it wrong, all other players in turn (except the question reader) are given a chance. If all fail, the card is placed in the so-called "stumper" pile. After all cards have been asked, the stumper pile is revisited. Then, all players add up their points and he with the highest points wins.

name: Castel Cartes
description:
Players is building the castle by playing cards.

In his turn player places his cards on the table to match the colors on cards already placed for scoring maximum points.

He scores as many points how long is the edge of the castle in this color

The winner is the player who scores the most points at the end of the game.

name: Tic-Tac
description:
1930's party game.

There are 5 large, cardboard horses. Each horse is attached to a length of string. Up to 5 players can play but more can be included if they just bet on the result. Each player with a horse stands about ten feet away from the agreed finish line. Their line of string is attached to something substantial, like a dining room table. At the cry "They're Off!", players jiggle their string and their horse should start to move to towards the finish line. It will get pretty frenetic but that adds to the fun. First owner to get their horse to the finishing line wins.

name: Rifles & Rebels: Fighting the Civil War 1861-1865
description:
“IN GREAT DEEDS SOMETHING ABIDES. ON GREAT FIELDS SOMETHING STAYS." —Joshua Chamberlain

It's July 1863 and the Army of the Potomac is holding on. Yesterday the Johnnies hit hard and the line held. Today you are the leftmost flank of the army and must not give an inch of ground.
Though dulled by the morning mist, the shrill sound of a Rebel Yell is unmistakable. The Johnnies are on the move again.

Will you hold?

Rifles & Rebels is a unit based game where units are composed of 5 to 10 figures. In Rifles & Rebels you can choose from two sides and two arms with a total of four forces. You can be:

• Union Infantry
• Confederate Infantry
• Union Cavalry
• Confederate Cavalry
Whichever you choose you must lead one or more units of men through the war, the American Civil War, fighting when needed because it's all about victory and glory, and in some cases, just survival!
The cannon are booming, the troops mustering, and the fight is coming to you. Welcome to …

RIFLES & REBELS
Rifles & Rebels uses a floating scale which allows you to count each unit as a platoon, company, or battalion. This allows you to fight large battles as well as smaller actions.
Rifles & Rebels and Muskets & Mohawks share similar mechanics with changes made to reflect the different periods.

(From the producers website)

name: Unravel
description:
Kites are a fun way to spend an afternoon in the park– if only the wind wouldn’t keep tangling up the strings! Race against the other players each round to be the first to figure out who is holding the kite shown on the die roll. This is a great way for kids to practice holding attention and mentally tracing a route in their heads.

First, the players roll the die. This determines the color that is being tracked this turn. At the same time, all players should mentally follow the string from the kite down to figure out which character is holding the other end of the string. Players must not use their fingers, just follow the string's path in their heads.

Once someone thinks they have the right answer, yell "STOP!" and grab the matching Solution Tile. Everyone checks together to see if this is the correct solution. Collect a Pinwheel for a correct answer, but lose a Pinwheel if you're wrong!

If you roll yellow and the yellow balloon is showing near the characters, players have to grab the Yellow Balloon Solution Tile instead of tracing the yellow kite's string. Similarly, if you roll orange and Squawk the parrot is showing near the kites, players have to grab the Squawk Solution Tile instead of tracing the orange kite's string. You lose a Pinwheel if you grab another Solution Tile when you should have chosen Squawk or the balloon!

The game comes with double-sided Character and Kite boards, and 2 double-sided and reversible String Boards to keep players guessing.

WHAT THEY'LL LEARN: Mental Mapping, Color Recognition, Quick Thinking

name: Ringmaster
description:
Contents: Boardgame, heroes and challenge (monsters) cards, dice and 3 pawns.
Objective: to defeat and collect all 21 cards.

The boardgame consists of 3 interlocked circles. Playes move their pawns on the the circles. If you land on a space marked by the name of a character you can collect that character card. Other spaces are marked as combat spaces. Landing on a combat space allows you to challenge other players.

The battle takes place by presenting a number of character cards (battle force) and adding some points from the weapon circle according to the dice throw.

The winner of the battle takes all the cards that took part on the battle. When one player has managed to collect all the cards of the game is declared winner.

name: Spelit
description:
Promotional card game, made by the Irish company Lyons, who sell tea in Ireland and Great Britain.

Each player is dealt ten cards. The undealt cards are laid seperately in the centre of the table face down. The cards have either two letters or one letter on them and in one of four colours. In her turn, a player must choose one of the face down cards and then discard a card by returning a card from his hand by placing it face down in the centre of the table. However, before she does this, she must show it to all the other players. Now memory is added to the game because if you need a specific card, and you can remember that it was discarded earlier, it would be beneficial to recall where it is in the face down cards.

The object is to collect cards that spell out the words GREEN LABEL (the company's most famous brand). This could be as few as 5 cards (using double letter cards) or as many as 10 cards (using single letter cards). The first to do so, wins.

name: Kill dog
description:
In Kill dog, players are mafiosis trying to get the largest share of the loot.
Armed with a gun and some bullets, they will try to intimidate other mafia in the house!

The player with the most money at the end of the game is the winner.

The pre-version of Ca$h 'n Gun$ was published in french magazine "Jeux sur un plateau" (Games on a board) No. 09 with no guns included.
categories: Bluffing, Fighting, Humor, Mafia, Negotiation, Party Game

name: Gomston, A Polluted City
description:
Designed as a classroom game which will teach children about the dangers of pollution. Players must make decisions relating to pollution spread or to pollution control. Best played in teams. The winning team would be the one with least pollution at the end of the game or lesson.

Incredibly heavy, I cannot remember a board game that was as physically heavy as this one.

The game even has a cassette tape and a roll of film.

name: Duotronic
description:
Played on a 12x12 board, this is a fast and easy to understand game where opponents try to possess as many squares as possible on a shrinking playing area.
Players take turns placing one stone anywhere on the cells of the board. Once placed, a stone cannot be moved unless it is captured.
Capturing: there are two ways to do this, either by placing one of your stones between two of your opponent's stones (which are then captured), or by sandwiching one of your opponent's stones (which is then captured) between two of yours, or between one of your stones and the edge of the board or an obstruction in any direction.
Obstructions: when a stone is captured it is removed from the board and replaced with an obstruction (these can be represented by coins, buttons, bits of paper, mosaic tiles, etc.) that cannot be played on, effectively removing the cell from the board.
Winning: the player with the most stones on the board after every cell has been occupied or obstructed wins.

name: Storstadsbilist
description: Humorous game about destructive city planning. One player takes the role as the city planner, and the others are commuters. The city planner blocks roads in order to stop the commuters from getting to and from work. The commuters move by dice rolls on a simple city grid, which gradually gets less and less interconnected. The commuters can build tunnels by democratic vote to overcome some obstacles.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Tile Placement, Voting

name: Zug
description:
This game was invented by D. J. Springgay who is a well-known chess player, so the game is worthy of attention. Zug is an abstract game for two players with simple rules and fairly obvious affinities to several well-known games and has been well tested in practice. A provisional patent application for the game was filed in October, 1971.

The game is played on a square board composed of 17 squares by 17 alternately coloured light and dark, the corner squares being dark. Two lines marked on the board are called advance lines (between the 4th and 5th rank and the 13th and 14th rank depending on the end you are starting).
These are of two contrasting colours but otherwise identical. Each player has twelve. The player of the dark pieces places nine men on rank 1 and the remaining three on any squares on rank two. The player of the light pieces does the same on ranks 17 and 16 respectively.

The players are referred to as Black (the player of the dark pieces) and White, regardless of the colours of the men.

The object of the game is to be the first to move all one’s pieces to the opposite end of the board such that the 1st (17th) rank is occupied by nine pieces with the remaining three pieces on the 2nd (16th) rank.

A piece may jump over one or more other pieces of either colour provided that each jump is over an adjacent piece to a vacant square and in a forward direction only.

Neither player may play a piece to the end rank unless all his pieces are forward of his advance line. When a player has all his pieces forward of his opponent’s advance line, he is permitted to move pieces backwards if he wishes.

name: Freeze
description:
Once again the checker board provides the basis for a game, only this time the size grid required is 10x10.

In 'Freeze' the movement of each playing piece is dependent upon its position on the board in relation to the other pieces. The object of the game is to prevent one's opponent from moving any of his pieces.

Each of the players has ten cube-shaped pieces, the two sets being of contrasting colours. During the game, a piece can be in one of three states: free, polarised or frozen. Thus the faces of the cubes are marked, so that the one facing upper most indicates its current state. These marks are:
Plain face — free
A line (either diagonally or orthogonally) — polarised
A large central dot — frozen.

A cube moves according to the state that it is in, as follows:
Free — any distance in any direction (as the Queen in chess)
Polarised — any distance along the line of polarisation
Frozen — no movement

To start the game, the pieces are set up in opposite corners, with the three corner pieces being in a free state and the remainder diagonally polarised towards the opponent's corner. Players choose who is to start and then move one of their pieces alternately. No piece may move over or onto any occupied square.

The state of pieces change as follows:
If two free, opposing pieces come into line, diagonally or orthogonally, without any other piece between them, then both become polarised and are turned to show a polarised face with the line in the correct direction.
If a piece becomes polarised along two different lines, it becomes frozen and is unable either to move or to polarise or freeze opposing pieces.

The action of freezing a piece may well release one or more pieces that were under its influence before it was frozen. When a polarised or frozen piece becomes separated from a piece which was polarising it, by the intervention of another piece, it is no longer under the influence of that piece and may move up to the next advantageous state; thus a frozen cube becomes polarised and a polarised one is freed. Any piece may change its state by the movement of any other piece on the board, whether friendly or enemy. Each such move can easily set off a chain reaction. It is the responsibility of each player to point out those opposing pieces which have become polarised or frozen as the result of a move. He should also note when his own pieces are freed.

The winner is the player who first freezes all of his opponents pieces.

name: Ant Heap
description:
Game from Games and Puzzles magazine, issue 38.

The game is for 2-6 players and is played on a board laid out as shown in the diagram. Each track or run is in two parts, the Base along the edge of the board, and the Approach. Each pair of Base and Approach runs would be of a different colour, but are lettered in the diagram for the purpose of identification. Each player would have a cube, of the same colour as his track. This cube is marked from 1-6 in a similar fashion to a dice, but with ants replacing the usual spots. A collection of ants' eggs with a container and a normal die complete the equipment. The eggs are quite simple to make from papier mache, plaster or a similar substance and painted white.

At the start of the game, the eggs are placed in the container, which in turn is placed in the Queen Ant's Nest in the middle of the board. The cubes are situated in their respective bases with the side showing the six ants uppermost. The die is thrown in turn, and the cubes moved the appropriate number of squares in the direction indicated, along the Base run and then up the Approach run.

The first player to reach his X on the Ant Nest surround, stops on that square and becomes the Defender of the Queen Ant's Nest. All other ants to reach their X's during that turn become Attackers, and attack the Defender. These attacks are resolved as follows: both players throw the die and the highest score wins, a draw counting as a win for the Defender. When the Defender wins, he remains where he is, and the Attacker returns to that square on his Approach run, having the same number as that thrown by the Defender. If the Attacker wins, he becomes the Defender, while the ousted Defender goes back to the square on his Base run having the same number as that thrown by the Attacker. Should a Defender be beaten by a throw of 6, he is returned to his Base and loses one ant from his group, and so recommences with the new ant group showing face up on the cube. A player with only one ant is knocked out of the game when beaten by an Attacker's throw of 6. On his turn, a Defender must attempt to circumnavigate the Nest, in accordance with throws of the die, and defend himself each time he lands on an opponent's X square containing a cube. When he returns to his own X, he stops (regardless of the throw) and is entitled to collect eggs as follows:

Size of
Ant Group
6-5 = 3 eggs
4-3 = 2 eggs
2-1 = 1 egg

Play continues until all the eggs have been removed from the nest. The initial number of eggs is optional, but an ideal number is 30. The winner is the player having most eggs at the end of the game.

Although it may sound complicated, 'Antheap' is in fact very simple to play. It is well worth going to the trouble of making the board and the cubes, for it will certainly provide the younger members of the family with hours of fun.

name: Double Dealer
description:
DOUBLE DEALER: Auction Americana With A Sly Twist!

Object of the Game: The object of “Double Dealer” is to buy antiques listed on your client cards at auction and resell at a profit. It is important that players try to buy the combination of antiques listed on their client cards, since they are worth more together than when sold singly. The winner is the player who has the most money after cashing in his antiques at the end of the game.

One of the "big box" Hasbro family fun games from the mid 70’s, which also included The Great Estate, Power Broker, and High Stakes. On the cover of each of these huge games is a similar picture with similar people, and a game quote from Jerry Lewis. For Double Dealer the quote is: “You’re hot…buy low, sell high…wheel and deal, then double deal. That’s the name of the game!” – Jerry Lewis

name: Arabistan Fleet
description:
"Arabistan Fleet is a contemporary game of naval warfare taking place in Middle East, focusing on Persian Gulf and Iran.
Time Scale :
- 8 hours per turn
- 80 km per hex.

The players maneuver war ships, submarines, aircrafts, amphibious war ships and cargos on a map covering Asia from Iran to Indonesia.

The game reuse rules from Victory Games Fleet series, but includes new weapons as missiles, ground lauched ballistic missiles, SAM, cruise missiles
There are also new rules regarding submarines, Aegis ships, anti-missile defence systems, long range air-to-air missile,

The game can be linked with Arab-Israel Fleet.

More Information:

The game includes 6 scénario, from very simple to more complex ones:

1/ Fateful Closing
2/ Gulf Incident
3/ Nuclear Strike
4/ Escort Fleet
5/ Storm over Karachi
6/ Revolt in Middle East"

name: Folring
description: Folring is a two-player abstract game played on a circular board. Embedded within the circle are 19 interlocking hexes. Because of the interlocking, a single vertex can be part of as many as six hexes. The players take turns placing, moving, and jumping their pieces from one vertex to another until one player's pieces occupy all six vertices of one hex.

name: Cuisinons
description:
French card game aimed at youngsters to get them interested in food preparation.

Eight recipe cards are placed in the centre of the table. Each player gets six random ingredient cards. In a turn, a player must place one ingredient if he can, to one of the recipe cards. He then replenishes his hand. Play proceeds until one recipe card is completed with all its ingredients. The player who laid the final ingredient claims the recipe card which will be worth a number of points. The more ingredients a recipe needs, the more points it is worth.

When all the recipes are claimed, the player with the most points, wins.

name: Tide of Battle
description:
Tide of Battle is a customizable card game for 2 or 4 players.

Players take on the role of martial artists in combat with each other. Each player has a deck of 30 Tide of Battle cards, each card representing a martial arts technique. These cards are played as attacks or defenses against one another, with successful attacks subtracting from a target player's HP. A player begins with 30 HP and is knocked out, losing the game when that player reaches 0 HP.

name: Flattermax
description:
Whoever is skillful enough to flick the bat off into his or her own compartment gets a star. The game ends when a player has 3 stars in his/her compartment and thus wins the game.

The rules contain also special rules for advanced players and for young children.

name: Urban
description:
This game has been created with the objective in mind of entertaining everyone from age 7 to age 99 while they learn or remember everything necessary about road safety.
In order to do so, we will be placed on a city where we will have to drive following the indications made by the local police, the visual signs, the roadmarkings, and several obstacles upon arriving at our destination.

name: 90er Jahre Quiz
description:
Quiz of the Decade series from Noris publisher attributes the players in the 90s. Each participant tries to get through right answer as many questions of quiz cards. Who has the most cards at the end in his possession wins the game.

The quiz cards are shuffled and placed in a pile in the middle of the table. There are six categories: 1) History & Politics, 2) literature and film, 3) Sports & Games, 4) Technology & Cars, 5) music and 6) Misc.
The active player rolls the dice and one player takes the bottom card from the pile and reads the corresponding question. Now the player must choose one of four answer choices, because only one of the answers is correct.

name: Das DDR Quiz
description:
What profession learned Erich Honecker? Which product has been sold under the brand name "Erika"?
These and similar questions must be answered in this game.
For each question, you get 3 answers. Answer correctly and move forward with character on the game board.
Player who finishes first is the winner.

name: Geschlechterkampf 2
description:
You can play Battle of the Sexes 2 in two variants, either as a team game, "women against men" or as individual players' every man for himself.

There are fewer chips than first version of the game.

In his turn the team roll the dice what determines the question to be asked. There are five questions and their answers on each card. If "6" is rolled the random question is chosen.
They reads out a question that must now discuss the other team, offered possible answers which could well be the correct or may be bluff. Other team must answer correctly to move their pawn accordinglyon the game board.
Team who finish first is the winner.
categories: Card Game, Mature / Adult, Party Game, Trivia

name: RTL Boxen
description:
Players are managers of one or more boxers by training and sending them a ring, winning advertising contracts and negotiating the profit exchanges.
There is also possible to bet to boxers You think to win.

The ranking is determined by dice the fighting with the boxing cards and boxing dice.

The game is played over an entire season, the victory decide the highest revenue.
categories: Card Game, Dice, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Sports

name: Lilly Frog
description:
In essence, Lilly Frog is a 4-in-a-row game for two players. The game is played on a 6x6 checkered board. The pattern consists of green water lilly leaves and purple lotus flowers. The playing pieces (6 per player) are cutely crafted wooden frogs in the same colors.

In the initial set-up 3 frogs per player are standing on both baselines; green frogs start on the green leaves, purple frogs on the purple flowers.

A turn consists of moving a frog of the own player color to an adjacent, free space. The color of the spaces doesn't matter any more at this point. The first player to get 4 frogs in a row, wins the game.

A game variant with hopping frogs allows for a faster game.

Lilly Frog is part of the same series as ChessQuito of the same editor.

name: The Glory that Was Vol. I: Greece. Episode IV – Socrates' Battles
description:
Fourth entry in the Glory that was Greece series, is a print and play game dedicated to two battles from the Peloponnesian War, Delium 424 BC and Amphipolis 422 BC. The famous greek philosopher Socrates took part in both of these campaigns, and fought with valor.
The game uses a medium complexity system, with specific rules for the various kind of arms (hoplites, peltasts, cavalry, etc.) and their interaction. There are two integrated combat resolution charts, rules for leaders and their influence on the field of battle (both as aid in combat than in morale checks) and also optional rules with the use of combat cards for getting more variable in the combat phase.
mechanics: Card Play Conflict Resolution, Dice Rolling

name: Code Lyoko JCC: Attaque de X.A.N.A.
description:
Object of the game is to control the heros from the cartoon and help them to defeat XANA.

Each player uses up to five heroes who carry out specific actions and face certain dangers to score points. Victory points can also be earn by playing some cards.

The winner is the first player to reach 20 points.

Starter deck contains 165 card.
There are two starter decks available: "Alert on Lyoko" and "The secret is in danger"
categories: Collectible Components, Fantasy, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Ekebet
description:
"Deep in the Jungle the Ekebet, Mayan star messangers compete in the dangerous ritual race to bring glory to their city state. They must run day and night to reach the oposite city state before anyone else. With Kukulkan´s help, the great serpent god, they call for ancient power to reach victory".

An abstract game set in the Mayan culture for 2 to 4 players. Each player has a set of four runners that starts in their home city state and must run across to board, a jungle, to reach the oposite side, another city state. The player who reaches the oposite city state first with all his runners win the game. The pices movements are managed by a set of movement pieces. Each runner and each movement piece has two sides: day and night. When a runner moves, his piece change it´s side to a new status (day to night or night to day). Players need to manage their movement pieces in order to move their runners in the board according to their status each round. Some animals in the jungle block the runners path and each player can call for Kukulkan aid, special poker tokens that bend the general game rules.

name: Mega Bloks Memory Builder
description:
MEGA Bloks Memory Builder is a memory and matching game using 20 plastic maxi Mega Bloks in 4 different colours with animal pictures on them. These blocks are hidden randomly in a 'field' - a cardboard insert within the game box. Players can't see the animals, only the colored tops of the Mega Bloks. Each player takes one of four double-sided 'barn' cards showing a set of animals (four animals on each side, in four different colours). The cards have insert holes for a white Mega Bloks stand.

Players then take turns at pulling an animal block from the field, trying to be the first to find the four animals on their card. The first player to match all four animals on their barn card wins.

The game components are easy for small children to manage and the game is fun and challenging enough to hold interest. The double-sided cards allow some variety and replayability.
mechanics: Memory, Modular Board, Pattern Recognition, Set Collection

name: Il Gioco Gigante dell'Italia
description:
The game consists of two phases. In the first phase, a players assemble a large (100 cm x 70 cm) jigsaw puzzle map of Italy. In the second phase, players roll numbered and colored dice to place their tokens on cities and to place the special tiles representing the special landmarks of the regional capitals.

Players seek to place all of their tokens on cities and to place all of the regional capitals from their hands on to the board. The numbered die indicates the quantity of tokens that may be placed, while the colored die indicates who may play tokens or place a regional capital tile.

The first player to place all of her tokens and regional capital tiles wins the game.

name: Super Robot large remodeling plan
description:
Children game for Super Robot animations in 1970's. The game include six Super Robot from Getter Robo G(1975-76), Great Mazinger(1974-75), Grendizer(1975-77), Gaiking(1976-77), Chōdenji Robo Combattler V(1976-77) and Brave Raideen(1975-76).

Each Super Robot is represented by cards of six parts. Each card has a different power　number. The strength of the Super Robot is determined by the total power number of the six parts.

The game can play four types of rule. Mainly, players gathering the cards and rebuild a Super Robot. The cards gathering by using roulette, card drafting or random draw.

Players who built the most powerful Super Robot is the winner.
categories: Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Business Cycles
description:
Business Cycles is an abstract game of chance and risk aversion. In Business Cycles, players play the role of entrepreneurs or CEOs directing three separate businesses over the course of a 40 year career. The winner is the player who retires with the greatest lifetime earnings after shepherding her businesses across the board.

Business Cycles is played in turns; on a turn a player rolls two dice and moves one or two business tokens along the game board, which is a track with 40 spaces. Some spaces have positive effects, some negative, and some require the player to take a card, which may be positive, negative, or neutral. Players must use both dice if possible and two tokens may not occupy the same space. A player one of whose tokens lands on a positive (profit) space immediately takes another turn, and continues to do so until she ends a turn in which she has only landed tokens on negative or card-drawing spaces.

Bearing business tokens off at the end of the board must be done by an exact roll; once one player has borne off all of her businesses, each player who went after her in the initial turn order gets one more turn (so that all players will have had the same number of turns). At that point, the player with the most money wins the game.

name: ASL Comp: Digger Pack I
description:
Includes 212 counters providing Australian infantry among others, 8" x 22" geomorphic board (PTO1), and 12 scenarios.

DP #1 The O-Patchers! American Japanese 1945-02-01 Digger Pack I
DP #2 Volckmann's Guerillas Filipinos Japanese 1945-06-14 Digger Pack I
DP #3 Koepang Bang Japanese Australian/Dutch 1942-02-20 Digger Pack I
DP #4 Battle at Baliuag American Japanese 1941-12-31 Digger Pack I
DP #5 Oil Strike! Japanese Australian/British/Dutch 1942-02-14 Digger Pack I
DP #6 Night Dragons Japanese Australian 1942-08-26 Digger Pack I
DP #7 Deceptive Reception Japanese Australian 1942-01-14 Digger Pack I
DP #8 The South Side of Green New Zealand Japanese 1944-02-16 Digger Pack I
DP BONUS #1 Tenaru Tussle American Japanese 1942-08-21 Digger Pack I
DP BONUS #2 One Last Charge Australian Japanese 1942-01-20 Digger Pack I
DP BONUS #3 Biak Probe Japanese American 1944-06-15 Digger Pack I
DP BONUS #4 Lights Out American Japanese 1944-10-17 Digger Pack I
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Wargame, World War II

name: Greco
description:
The Mythology Game of Skill and Chance

Greco is a Mythology Bingo game. It is a learning/Bingo set put out by The Perfection Form Company of Logan, Iowa. A caller calls out a revealed piece, and in order to claim placement of the mythological character, you have to match it to the trivia blurb on your card.

Greco is pronounced with a long 'e', e.g. "Greek-o"

name: Quintazone-Chaser
description:
In original Quintazone, players create a surface of tiled cards with connections defined by matching the five elements of air, earth, fire, water, and space, and they score by occupying those cards with pyramids.

In Quintazone-Chaser, the game is extended, as the players roll a die to race across the cards and collect the pyramids that were placed in Quintazone. The Chaser plays faster than the original game, but can only be played directly after it.

In addition to the Aquarius Deck and Components: Looney Pyramid Games used in Quintazone, Quintazone-Chaser adds a unique token for each player and the color die from IceDice (or a regular numeric d6).

This expansion was originally published at IcehouseOrg.

name: Avengers Mighty Battle
description:
"Mighty Battle" is an epic clash between the Avengers and the Skrulls for possession of the Cosmic Cube!"

This is a dexterity and strategy game in which players choose the side of the Avengers while one player chooses to play as the Skrulls. The game contains 12 plastic Skrull "grunts" and 4 plastic Skrull commanders. These are arranged at one end of the table. Avenger players can be Iron Man, Hulk, Captain America, or Thor. The Avengers play as a team and must stop the Skrulls from reaching the center of the play area and capturing the Cosmic Cube. Each Avenger player can fire a special missile to knock down the Skrulls: Captain America has his shield, Iron Man his missles, Thor his mighty hammer, and Hulk hurls boulders.
